In Julia, Write a function `timezone_bumper(dt,bump)` that increases any provided timestamp by `bump::Int` hours (defaults to +3 hours). Make sure it works only for DateTime types and throws an error for Date types.

Here is the Julia code that performs this task:
```julia
function timezone_bumper(dt::DateTime; bump=3)
    # Check if input is DateTime type 
    if typeof(dt) != DateTime
        throw(ArgumentError("Input must be of DateTime type"))
    end

    return dt + Dates.Hour(bump)
end
```
This function will add a given number of hours to the provided timestamp, in this case 3 by default, but this can be changed with the second argument `bump`. The function throws an error if the input is not a DateTime object.
